summary: How I’ve always imagined Gendry’s proposal would go
title: How I’ve always imagined Gendry’s proposal would go
body:
I was going to put this into a fic and I still might, but for now I wanted to share it with all of you lovel Gendrya shippers.

Gendry walked into the tent with purpose, his mind on the one task at hand. Though his heart was pounding like a hammer on steel, his mind was made up. Arya stood facing away from him, her eyes on a table set with battle pieces. They had fled from Winterfell, with the remainder of their army making their way South. Arya had insisted on sharing a tent with him, but he had refused on account of Jon not being happy about it. She turned now.

“Oh, good, you’re here. I wanted to ask you about-”

“Arya,” he interrupted. “I need to say something to you, and I need to say it now before I lose courage.”

Arya raised an eyebrow. “Alright, what is it?”

Gendry took a breath. With her here before him now, it seemed like a much more impossible thing to do. He swallowed. “Arya, I’ve cared about you since we were both young. Through out my life, you have been the one person who has cared about me and wanted to protect me, just as much as I have you. And now, well now we are grown. And I want to protect you for the rest of my life, and I want you to protect me for the rest of your life.”

Arya half smiled. “Gendry, I’m not just going to up and abandon you. You know that.”

He nodded. “Yes, I know. But I want to make it more official. Arya, will you marry me?”

Arya’s smiled slipped from her face. “What? Stop messing around Gendry.”

“I’m not messing around.” He took several steps closer to her. “All of my life I have known nothing but uncertainty. Where my next meal would come from, when the gold cloaks were going to find me, if I was going to be sold off again. But you have been the one constant. I have always known that you will be there, if you could. I know you will fight for me. You’re the one thing I have ever wanted.”

Arya stared up at him, her face blank, but her eye full of a storm that he couldn’t understand. Finally, she shook her head. “No.”

Gendry let out a breath, his heart dropping to his stomach. But he had prepared for this. Arya wasn’t one to accept so easily. “Why not?”

She scoffed. “Because I don’t want to!”

“I don’t believe that. I love you, and I know you love me. Give me a better answer.”

Arya gritted her teeth. “I don’t have to give you anything!”

She shoved past him and walked out of the tent, leaving him alone and staring after her.

********************************

Arya stomped through the camp ground. How dare he? Did he not know her at all? She had told him all her life that she didn’t want to marry and be a Lady. She walked to the edge of a hill on the outskirts of camp, overlooking a valley. The wind swept her cloak away from her, but she barely felt it. She was too hot.

Why would Gendry do this? Was he trying ruin what they had? Maybe he was a coward and didn’t want to hurt her, so this was his way of making her push him away. Arya sighed. She knew this wasn’t true. Gendry was no coward. And he did love her. She could see it in his eyes, just as he saw it in hers. She didn’t hear her sister come to stand beside her, but she knew she was there without looking.

“Is everything alright?” Sansa asked.

Arya closed her eyes. “I don’t know.”

They were silent for several minutes before Arya spoke again. “You don’t believe in marriage, do you?”

Sansa didn’t answer at first. Arya glanced at her, and saw that her eyes were distant focused on the hills far beyond where they stood.

“I wouldn’t say that. I don’t believe in marriage for political purpose.”

Arya raised her eyebrows. “Then what’s the point?”

Sansa smiled. “I’ve only ever seen one healthy and happy marriage. Mothers and Fathers. And I know that it was hard, even though they loved each other. But I think they wouldn’t have had it any other way.”

“But how can one assure that a marriage will work? That they won’t tire of each other or grow resentful?”

Sansa sighed. “I think the key is equality. Both parties must have as much to give as they take. Love is good, but it’s not the only thing needed. They must respect each other as much as they love. And neither can ask something of the other that they would not be willing to give. Sort of like you and Gendry.”

Arya looked sharply at her sister. Sansa was smiling down at her with that knowing smile of hers. “I don’t think I’ve ever seen anyone respect someone as much as Gendry respects you and you him. Most would kill for a love like that.”

Arya looked away, and she knew what she had to do.

***************************

Gednry sat in the chair facing the table. Had he really just pushed her away for good? No, he wouldn’t allow that. She was stubborn, but so was he. A cold draft alerted him that someone had entered. He stood and turned, and she was there. He opened his mouth the speak, but she raised a hand to stop him. She stared at him, her mouth set in a hard line and her eyebrows knitted together.

“I won’t wear a dress.”

Gendry couldn’t help the laugh that escaped his mouth, but she didn’t smile. He nodded. “Ok, that’s fine.”

“And I won’t be a Lady, or tend your castles and halls. I won’t give you a dozen sons to be knights and princes. I won’t sit aside while you make all the decisions.”

He shrugged. “I would never ask you to.”

She crossed her arms. “And I won’t stop killing people!”

He smiled. “I wouldn’t try to stop you.”

She continues to frown at him for several seconds, until finally her expression softened and she smiled. “Then yes. I will marry you.”

********************************

She walked to the edge of a hill on the outskirts of camp, overlooking a valley. The wind swept her cloak away from her, but she barely felt it. She was too hot.

Why would Gendry do this? Was he trying ruin what they had? Maybe he was a coward and didn’t want to hurt her, so this was his way of making her push him away. Arya sighed. She knew this wasn’t true. Gendry was no coward. And he did love her. She could see it in his eyes, just as he saw it in hers. She didn’t hear her sister come to stand beside her, but she knew she was there without looking.

“Is everything alright?” Sansa asked.

Arya closed her eyes. “I don’t know.”

They were silent for several minutes before Arya spoke again. “You don’t believe in marriage, do you?”

Sansa didn’t answer at first. Arya glanced at her, and saw that her eyes were distant focused on the hills far beyond where they stood.

“I wouldn’t say that. I don’t believe in marriage for political purpose.”

Arya raised her eyebrows. “Then what’s the point?”

Sansa smiled. “I’ve only ever seen one healthy and happy marriage. Mothers and Fathers. And I know that it was hard, even though they loved each other. But I think they wouldn’t have had it any other way.”

“But how can one assure that a marriage will work? That they won’t tire of each other or grow resentful?”

Sansa sighed. “I think the key is equality. Both parties must have as much to give as they take. Love is good, but it’s not the only thing needed. They must respect each other as much as they love. And neither can ask something of the other that they would not be willing to give. Sort of like you and Gendry.”

Arya looked sharply at her sister. Sansa was smiling down at her with that knowing smile of hers. “I don’t think I’ve ever seen anyone respect someone as much as Gendry respects you and you him. Most would kill for a love like that.”

Arya looked away, and she knew what she had to do.

***************************

Gednry sat in the chair facing the table. Had he really just pushed her away for good? No, he wouldn’t allow that. She was stubborn, but so was he. A cold draft alerted him that someone had entered. He stood and turned, and she was there. He opened his mouth the speak, but she raised a hand to stop him. She stared at him, her mouth set in a hard line and her eyebrows knitted together.

“I won’t wear a dress.”

Gendry couldn’t help the laugh that escaped his mouth, but she didn’t smile. He nodded. “Ok, that’s fine.”

“And I won’t be a Lady, or tend your castles and halls. I won’t give you a dozen sons to be knights and princes. I won’t sit aside while you make all the decisions.”

He shrugged. “I would never ask you to.”

She crossed her arms. “And I won’t stop killing people!”

He smiled. “I wouldn’t try to stop you.”

She continues to frown at him for several seconds, until finally her expression softened and she smiled. “Then yes. I will marry you.”

body:
Predictions:

1. Dany will try to kill Jon.

2. The Crypt Starks are the good guys.

3. Dany will contemplate killing Jon.

4. They forgot to arm anyone in the crypts.

5. Dany will contemplate saving Jon.

6. Bran continues to be creepy.

7. Dany almost lets Jon die.

8. Arya saves Sansa.

9. Dany….maybe loves Jon more than the throne? But does she love Aegon?

10. Someone thought to arm themselves on the way to the crypts.

blog.name: partywithponies
blog.title: Crying into my cheeky Nando's
blog.description:
Hi.
I love you.
Yes, you. You're beautiful.
And don't you forget it.
I'm Tasha, 23, from London, England. I love various British comedies, Death in Paradise, Father Brown, Doctor Who, Midsomer Murders, Eurovision, Casualty, Holby, old sci-fi, and many kid's shows (mostly CBBC, CBBC is my life.)
Feel free to send me an ask any time! Tell me about your day! Ask me about my OTPs! Tell me about your OTPs! I'll listen.

summary: An ideal version of GoT would be a version where it's literally nothing but scenes of Bran creeping people out while Sansa and...
body: An ideal version of GoT would be a version where it’s literally nothing but scenes of Bran creeping people out while Sansa and Arya proudly watch on like “this is my brother, he’s very weird and slightly terrifying, I love him so much”, all episode, every episode. Occasional filler scenes of Sansa having a lovely time and people being nice to her also acceptable.

summary:
"What do we say to The God of Death?"  "Not today."  I was working
 on some thumbnails for a different piece and this one just...
caption:
“What do we say to The God of Death?”
“Not today.”
I was working on some thumbnails for a different piece and this one just kinda happened, so I spent some time and fleshed it out.
I really, really want Arya to survive The Battle of Winterfell!

summary: The way he looks at her...
body: The way he looks at her…

reblog.comment: The way he looks at her…

trail.content_raw: The way he looks at her…
trail.content: The way he looks at her…

body:
Gendry x Arya

I’m very pro Gendry/Arya. I’m more of a fan of Gendry than I am Arya if I’m honest.

There’s so much shared history and trauma.

Like so many other people have said they balance each other out and he brings back her humanity. Plus due to their time travelling together he understands parts of her history/motivations that none of the starks have seen or would fully understand.

I’ve been waiting for the reunion forever so was so delighted that it happened in 8.01 and they became canon in 8.02.

Fingers crossed nothing happens to either of them- seems like too much build up and potential resolutions to off one in the big battle (but who knows).

I know a lot of people’s end game for them is them being Lord/lady of Winterfell, storm lands or somecases the king and queen. Honestly I can’t see that and think it would be disappointing. Neither of them have the head or experience for ruling. Plus we’ve seen how ruthless and driven by emotions Arya can be. Neither of them have shown any interest either

summary:
People think Jon Snow is the next Robb Stark. He is a fighter and a believer in the truth.  He is the next Young Wolf.
People...
body:
People think Jon Snow is the next Robb Stark. He is a fighter and a believer in the truth. He is the next Young Wolf.

People think Arya Stark is the next Robb Stark. She is determined and stubborn and brave. She is the next Young Wolf, along with her brother.

People think that Sansa Stark is the next Robb Stark. She is passionate and driven, and wholly believes in Northern Independance. She is not a fighter, but a politician. She is the next Ruler of the North.

The truth is that all the Stark children carry a little bit of Robb with them, in everything they do.

(People thought Bran Stark was the next Robb Stark. He was Winterfell’s little lord. But he went North, and a Raven flew back.)

summary: Soooo the lack if safety in the crypts totally went ove rms head till I saw your commentary and remembered that scene of Arya...
question: Soooo the lack if safety in the crypts totally went ove rms head till I saw your commentary and remembered that scene of Arya running in the trailer. Such a bad idea, those poor people,  lmao. This episode is gonna be so good and disturbing.
answer: ahhhhhh i wish we didn’t even have that clip of arya running because it’s only made the stress leading up to the episode today that much worse. my sister and i thought of a theory tho where the significance of the crypts might be the dead starks in them, but instead of attacking the heroes, they’ll rise up to defend them? sort of like the army of the dead in lotr. but who knows? i’m terrified no matter what, but at least we’re in this together?
